content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It fits in the easy category: just a nice puzzle that extends the normal Fibonacci mathematics, challenging enough to lift it beyond the size of a Clash but doable enough to solve it in a shorter time (or, for beginning coders, to solve it at all).

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: intéressant les variantes de Fibonacci

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I like this puzzle and I think "easy" is okay. The easy level puzzler has most likely heard of the Fibonacci sequence. Without being trivial, nor being super complex, this puzzle does a nice job of asking the puzzler to demonstrate their understanding of the Fibonacci sequence.
Input 1st Line - F1 should be F0

Like Timinator, I got a bit confused by the N and n, but ignoring the textual details and focusing on the general description it is a nice puzzle. And, the formula 'Fn = F(n-2) + F(n-3)' did help me in thinking up the solution.
- The order of the sentences in the statement can be changed. The formula Fn = F(n-2) + F(n-3) is only correct if every pair of rabbits gives birth to one pair of rabbits, so that should be mentioned before the formula. I would suggest the following statement text: "... the age (in years) the rabbits can reproduce. Each pair of rabbits will always give birth to one pair of rabbits per year of reproduction. For example, if rabbits can reproduce from the age of 2 to 3 years (inclusive), the number of rabbits born in year n (Fn) is the sum of the number of pairs two and three years before that year: Fn = F(n-2) + F(n-3).

The consistent use of rabbits vs pairs of rabbits is important. All numbers in this puzzle are about 'pairs of rabbits', so I suggest that you consistently talk about pairs.
- 'you will have to calculate how many rabbits will be born' -> 'you will have to calculate how many pairs of rabbits will be born';
- 'Those rabbits will always give birth to... -> 'Each pair of rabbits will always give birth to...'

I like this little puzzle a lot. However, the way you have chosen to demonstrate the Fibonacci relationship doesn’t work for me. Here’s why:

From Goal:
>> you will have to calculate how many rabbits will be born at a given moment

Input Spec:
>> and N, representing the number of years to simulate

To me, this all means that the “given moment” that needs to be calculated is “n” years into the future. I’m pretty sure you will agree with all of that. 

Now let’s look at test case 1. N=10, a=1, b=2. Re-writing this input per your example, gives us:

F(n+2) = F(n+1) + F1

I’m pretty sure you agree that to solve this test case we actually need to calculate F(10), right? How many pair of rabbits will be born on the 10th year after F1 is introduced into the system. 

The way your formula is written above, I’m tempted to plug 10 in for “n” and try to calculate F(12). After all, the input told me n=10. Or maybe I’m confident that I need to solve for F(10), which leads me to believe N is actually 8 in your formula and them I’m just confused. 

For me, this puzzle became very easy and straightforward when I quit looking at the example and I went back to the more common Fibonacci representation for test case 1:

F(n) = F(n-1) + F(n-2)

The number of rabbits born in the nth year after F1 is the sum of the number of rabbits that are one year old, and the number of rabbits that are two years old, per the given reproductive years.

I’m stuck on the goal. If I don’t read anything past the goal, should I know what “n” is referencing? I have read the goal multiple times over the last several hours, thinking I must be missing something, but I have no idea what F(n+3) = F(n+1) + Fn means. I’m definitely open to being shown that I am missing the obvious, so, if that is the case, let me have it!
I do not understand the second birth control test (number 10). To get the number of rabbits to zero, the initial rabbits would have to die, There is no mention of dying in the text

Goal section
* Please add "be" between "will" and "born".

* Please change "note" to "denote".

* Please remove the line break after "F1)".

* Please change "procreate" to "reproduce" (2 times).

* The word "generation" is used in a confusing way here. For example, in "Birth Control" Validator, the rabbits give birth every 3 time units, which means that there is one new generation every 3 time units. In other words, 1 time unit does not necessarily mean 1 generation.

Hence, assuming "year" is the time unit used, I would suggest to change "generation 1" to "year 1", and add "(in years)" after "the age".

* Please mention the assumption that each pair of rabbits always gives birth to one pair each time.

(Because, you know, if each pair of rabbits gives birth to 1 rabbit or 3 rabbits each time, the calculation is entirely different.)

Input section
* Please change "Integer" to "space-separated integers" (note the plural form).

* Please change "rabbit's pairs" to "pairs of rabbits".

* Please delete "at F1". Explanation: You either use Fn to denote "the number of newly born rabbits in Year n", or to denote "Year n" itself. It will be confusing if you mix up both uses.

* Please change "the simulation time" to "the number of years to simulate".

* Please change "an inclusive range representing the age" to "representing the inclusive range of age (in years)".

* Please change "rabbit" to "rabbits".

Output section
* Please change "rabbit's pairs" to "pairs of newly born rabbits".

* Please change "of generation" to "in year".

* Please format N as a [[variable]].

Constraints section / Cases
* Please fix the following inconsistency between the constraints and the cases:

   • The "No bunny" cases violate "1 ≤ Rabbits ≤ 100".

   • The "Birth control" cases violate "0 ≤ N ≤ 60".

Input section / Constraints section / Stub generator
* Suggest to change [[Rabbit]] to [[F1]], in the same way that you have used [[FN]].

Cases
* Currently all the cases are either "a = 1" or "a = b". Suggest to revise/add some cases to introduce more variety.

Thanks.
Thanks for your feedback.
It's because it is the number of newly born rabbits, the old ones are still there but we don't count them for the answer

If n is today, does that mean that in three years I will have today’s number of rabbits plus next year’s number of rabbits? If that is the case, what happened to year 2’s rabbits?

You mentioned F1. So I guess n=1 at some point. And therefore, F4 = F2 + F1? Am I correct then that F3 has nothing to do with the results of F4?

Right, I see why you're confused and maybe it wasn't very clear, for the case that you give here, you have to output F10 as you said. I used n and N distinctly, n is for the recurrence formula and can range from 1 to N. and N is the number of years. You shouldn't plug n = 10, I see now why you're tempted but that's not it, I'm going to rewrite the formula it will be clearer, thanks.
Thanks, I didn't see those, I already corrected most of the "rabbits" to "pair of rabbits". I'm correcting that right away, as well as the order in the statement

I appreciate your patience with me. 

>> To do so, you will know how many pairs of rabbits you introduce at year 1 (we'll denote them as F1)

Isn’t it true that “year 1” as used here is really referencing year zero of the simulation? In test case 1, we are asked to simulate 10 years past “year 1”. Seems to me that 10 years past year 1 is year 11. Why isn’t your statement written like this:

>> To do so, you will know how many pairs of rabbits you introduce at the beginning of the simulation (we'll denote them as F0).

In test case 1, the final answer is F11, right? If that’s true, I think that is too confusing for an “easy” level puzzle.

N is generation number, right?

n refers to simulation year, right?

So in simulation year 3, generation 4 is produced. I don’t think “N” is really part of your input. I believe the input is “n”. As you have said, these two are distinct, and I am not convinced that the problem statement is truly keeping them distinct.

What do you think of changing N to G or something like that just to see what it looks like? I think the easy level puzzler could very possibly struggle with the problem statement having both n and N.

My bad, I guess I really didn't check those details before publishing, it is indeed 10 years after the begining so you have to output F11, the same result can be achieved by introducing rabbit at year 0 so I'll do that.

The input is N, the final term we want to output, It can't be n as n is just an index, it varies. Maybe changing n to another letter can help so I will but I'm not quite sure I exactly get what you say.
Everything works for me now. Having generation number line up with simulation year removed all my concerns.
I see, well thanks for the feedback anyway

I don't think it is that hard, maybe I didn't said it well enough though.
To take back the example, F(n+3) = F(n+1) + Fn
Say we have 4 rabbits at year 1, so F1 = 4
the formula gives us F2 = F0 + F(-1), as the first term is F1, there is no rabbit in F0 and F(-1) so no rabbits are born in year 2.
F3 = F1 + F0, one again, no rabbit in F0 so F3 = F1 = 4, so 4 new rabbits are born in year 3
F4 = F2 + F1, as calculated above, F2 = 0 so F4 = F1 = 4
and so on: F5 = 4, F6 = 8, F7 = 8, until the n-th term
I'm not really sure I'm being any clearer, let me know if I wasn't

I get it now. I think I'm more used to seeing it written this way:

F(n) = F(n-2) + F(n-3)

Thank you for making the changes. Some minor follow-up:

Goal section
* Please change "in year" to "(in years)" [add brackets, use plural form].

* Please change "the rabbit" to "the rabbits".

* Please add "each year of reproduction" after "one pair".

Input section
* Please change "pair" to "pairs".

* Please change "Integer" to "space-separated integers".

* Please change "in years" to "(in years)" [add brackets].

* Please change "rabbit" to "rabbits".

Output section
* Please change "pair" to "pairs".

Thanks.
